document.docAuthor: Toporkova, Yana Y. & Smirnova, Elena O. & Mukhtarova, Lucia S. & Gorina, Svetlana S. & Grechkin, Alexander N.
document.docTitle: Catalysis by allene oxide synthases (CYP74A and CYP74C): Alterations by the Phe/Leu mutation at the SRS-1 region

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Catalysis by allene oxide synthases (CYP74A and CYP74C): Alterations by the Phe/Leu mutation at the SRS-1 region

paragraph.docAuthor: , Elena O . Smirnova, Lucia S . Mukhtarova, Svetlana S . Gorina,

subSection.paragraph:
Alexander N. Grechkin
∗∗

paragraph.emphasis: Kazan Institute of Biochemistry and Biophysics, FRC Kazan Scientific Center, Russian Academy of Sciences, P. O . Box 30, Kazan, 420111, Russia

subSection.paragraph: A R T I C L E I N F O

Lycopersicon esculentum Physcomitrella patens Linum
usitatissimum CYP
74 family Site-directed mutagenesis Allene oxide synthase Epoxyalcohol synthase Oxylipins
A B S T R A C T

Several catalytically significant regions called the substrate recognition sites (SRSs) have been uncovered within the P450 primary structure ( Gotoh, 1992 ; Zawaira et al., 2011 ; Dueholm et al., 2015 ). Some of them constitute the walls of the catalytic cavity, for instance, the I-helix ( Werck-Reichhart and Feyereisen, 2000 ; Denisov et al., 2005 ; Bak et al., 2011 ). Furthermore, the experiments on site-directed mutagenesis revealed some primary determinants within the SRSs, which govern the type of catalysis ( Roussel et al., 2000 ; Zawaira et al., 2008 ; Hughes et al., 2008 ; Lee et al., 2008 ; Toporkova et al., 2008 , 2013 , 2018a ). One of these determinants, namely the Phe 137, was uncovered from the 3D-structure of
Arabidopsis thaliana
AOS (AtAOS, CYP74A1) ( Lee et al., 2008 ). This site is localised at the distal face of haem iron. Phe residue as this site in AOS sequences controls reactivity of epoxyallylic radical and its cation by reaction with an aromatic π- system ( Lee et al., 2008 ). The F 137L mutant form of AtAOS exhibited mainly the HPL activity (as well as the minor AOS activity) in contrast to the WT enzyme ( Lee et al., 2008 ). All studied AOSs have the conserved Phe residue at this site (referred to as “ F / L toggle” ( Toporkova et al., 2018a )), while all HPLs and DESs have the Leu residue. The Leu/ Phe mutations at this site of selected CYP74 C HPLs led to a higher proportion of AOS activity compared to the WT enzymes ( Toporkova et al., 2018a ). For further elucidation of role of this putative determinant of kind of CYP74 enzymes catalysis, the effect of Phe/Leu mutations at “ F / L toggle” on the specificity of selected AOSs (CYP74A and CYP74 C subfamilies) has been studied in the present work.

footnote.paragraph: Abbreviations: AOS , allene oxide synthase; EAS , epoxyalcohol synthase; HPL , hydroperoxide lyase; DES , divinyl ether synthase; 9-H(P)OD, (9 S ,10E,12Z)-9-hydro (pero)xy-10,12-octadecadienoic acid; 9-H(P)OT, (9 S ,10E,12Z,15Z)-9-hydro(pero)xy-10,12,15-octadecatrienoic acid; 13-H(P)OD, (9Z,11E,13 S )-13-hydro(pero)xy- 9,11-octadecadienoic acid; 13-H(P)OT, (9Z,11E,13 S ,15Z)-13-hydro(pero)xy-9,11,15-octadecatrienoic acid; 10-oxo-PEA, 10-oxo-11-phytoenoic acid; IMAC, immobilised metal affinity chromatography; Me, methyl; TMS , trimethylsilyl; SRS, substrate recognition site

heading.emphasis: 2.1. Preparation and purification of the recombinant WT LeAOS3,
ZmAOS1, LuAOS, and PpAOS2 and their mutant forms

subSection.paragraph: The open reading frames (ORFs) of LuAOS (CYP74A1; GenBank P48417.1) and PpAOS2 (CYP74A8; GenBank XP_024372097.1) genes consisted of 1608 and 1425 nucleotides, respectively, and encoded 536 and 475 amino acid polypeptides, respectively. The ORFs have been cloned into the NdeI and XhoI restriction sites of the pET-23a vector (Novagen, USA ) using primer pairs LuAOScF/LuAOScR and PpAOS2cF/ PpAOS2cR ( Table 1 ), respectively, to yield the recombinant target proteins with His-tags at C-termini.

The following Phe/Leu mutant forms of AOSs were obtained by site-directed mutagenesis using the primers listed in Table 1 : LeAOS3 F 108 L , ZmAOS1 F 95 L , LuAOS F 155 L , and PpAOS2 F
93 L .
Multiple alignment of the target region of the CYP74 enzymes is presented in Fig. 1 . The recombinant WT enzymes and their mutant forms have been obtained in heterologous expression systems using
E. coli
cells. His-tagged recombinant WT proteins and their mutant forms were obtained and purified for biochemical characterisations.

heading.emphasis: 2.2. Analysis of reaction products of the WT enzymes

subSection.paragraph: In connection with the main aim of this work and for comparison with the WT enzymes, the mutant forms of studied AOSs were obtained and their catalytic properties were studied. The results are described in the following sections.

heading.emphasis: 2.3. Analysis of reaction products of the LeAOS3 F 108L mutant form

caption.paragraph: Oligonucleotide primers used for cloning and site-directed mutagenesis.

Fig. 1. Multiple alignments of partial sequences of following CYP74s: The multiple alignment of different CYP74 enzymes. The CYP74 family sequences: Lu, L. usitatissimum ; LuAOS, P48417.1; Zm, Z. mays ; ZmAOS1, AAR33048.1; Pp, P. patens ; PpAOS2, XP_024372097.1; St, Solanum tuberosum; StAOS3, CAI30876.1; StDES, NP_001305517.1; Le, L. esculentum ; LeAOS3, NP_001234833; LeHPL, CAB43022.1; LeDES, NP_001234527.1; Mt, Medicago truncatula; MtHPL, CAC86897; Ms, Medicago sativa; MsHPL CAB54849.1; At, A. thaliana ; AtHPL, AAC69871. Brackets highlighted the substrate recognition site SRS-1. F/L toggle is marked by the star symbol.

subSection.paragraph:
For further elucidation of the effect of Phe/Leu substitution, the following mutant forms of other AOSs were obtained: PpAOS2 F 93 L , ZmAOS1 F 95 L , and LuAOS F
155 L .
The catalytic properties of these mutant forms towards fatty acid hydroperoxides are described below.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 4. GC-MS analyses of products (Me/TMS) of 9( S )-HPOT conversions by recombinant WT ZmAOS1 ( А ), PpAOS2 F93L ( B ), and ZmAOS1 F95L ( C ). 2a and 2b , threo and erythro isomers of 9,10-dihydroxy-12,15-octadecadienoic acid; 5 , 9,10-epoxy-11-hydroxy-12,15-octadecadienoic acid; 11a and 11b , threo and erythro isomers of 9,10-epoxy-13-hydroxy-11,15-octadecadienoic acid; 13 , 9-hydroxynonanoic acid. The structural formulae of products are presented in Fig. 2. 9-HOT, (9 S ,10 E ,12 Z ,15 Z )-9-hydroxy-10,12,15-octadecatrienoic acid.

heading.emphasis: 2.4. Product specificities of the PpAOS2 F93L mutant form

document.paragraph: The WT PpAOS2 (data not illustrated) behaved as the specific AOS and produced mainly the α− ketols. In contrast, the mutant form PpAOS2 F93 L mutant form failed to produce any α− ketol upon incubations with 9( S )-HPOT ( Fig. 4B ) and 9( S )-HPOD ( Fig. 5B ). Instead, the predominant product 11 and the minor product 5 were formed from 9( S )-HPOT, while 9( S )-HPOD conversion led to products 4 and 12 . The mass spectrum of compound 11 possessed M+at m/z 396 (0.2%), [M + – Me] at m/z 381 (0.6%), [M + – MeO] at m/z 365 (0.1%), [M + – MeCH 2 CH = CHCH 2 ] at m/z 327 (14%), m/z 311 (12%), [327 – TMSOH] + at m/z 237 (18%), [M + – C10/C18] at m/z 185 (43%), [ CH 2 =O + -SiMe 3 ] at m/z 103 (27%), m/z 75 (50%), [SiMe 3 ] + at m/z 73 (100%). The spectrum approved the structure of the oxiranyl vinyl carbinol (EAS product) 9,10-epoxy-13-hydroxy-11,15-octadecadienoic acid (Me/TMS) for compound 11 . Compound 11 was represented by two epimers 11a (major) and 11b (minor), having the identical spectral patterns. The spectrum of product 5 exhibited M + at m/z 396 (0.2%), [M + – Me] at m/z 381 (0.4%), [M + – MeO] at m/z 365 (0.1%), [M + – TMSOH] + at m/z 306 (2.5%), [M + – C1/C8] at m/z 239 (3%), [M + – C1/C10] at m/z 197 (23%), m/z 131 (32%), [197 – TMSOH] + at m/z 107 (65%), [SiMe 3 ] + at m/z 73 (100%). The fragmentation patters, particularly the fragment at m/z 197, indicated the presence of a secondary alcohol moiety at C11 and overall the structure of the oxiranyl carbinol 9,10-epoxy-11-hydroxy-12,15-octadecadienoic acid (Me/TMS) – also EAS product – for product 5 . Thus, both products 11 and 5 are the epoxyalcohols – EAS products.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 3. Products (Me/TMS) of 9( S )-HPOD ( A and B ) and 13( S )-HPOD ( C and D ) conversions by recombinant WT LeAOS3 ( А and C ) and LeAOS F108 L mutant form ( B and D ). 1a and 1b , threo and erythro isomers of 9,10-dihydroxy-12- octadecenoic acid; 3 , 10-hydroxyphytonoic acid; 4 , 9,10-epoxy-11-hydroxy-12- octadecenoic acid; 6a and 6b , threo and erythro isomers of 12,13-dihydroxy-9- octadecenoic acid; 8 , 11-hydroxy-12,13-epoxy-9-octadecenoic acid; 10 , 9-hydroxy-12,13-epoxy-10-octadecenoic acid. The structural formulae of products are presented in Fig. 2. 9-HOD, (9 S ,10 E ,12 Z )-9-hydroxy-10,12-octadecadienoic acid.

Quantification of the AOS, HPL and EAS products produced by the mutant forms of AOSs upon incubations with fatty acid hydroperoxides. The NaBH 4 –reduced products (Me/TMS) were analysed by GC-MS. The peaks of epoxyalcohols (EAS products), 9-hydroxynonanoic acid (reduced 9-HPL product), (9 Z )-12-hydroxy-9- dodecenoic and (10 E )-12-hydroxy-10-dodecenoic acids (NaBH 4 -reduced 13-HPL products), as well as the 9,10- and 12,13-diols (α- ketol reduction products) in TIC chromatograms were quantified. Their percentage compositions are presented.

tableNote.paragraph: a tr., trace quantity (less than 1% of total products).

document.paragraph: The mass spectrum of compound 12 ( Fig. 5B ), the product of 9( S )- HPOD conversion by the PpAOS2 F93 L mutant form, possessed M + at m/z 398 (0.1%), [M + – Me] at m/z 383 (0.7%), [M + – MeO] at m/z 367 (0.5%), [M + – Me( CH 2 ) 4 ] at m/z 327 (14%), [M + – TMSOH] + at m/z 308 (2%), [327 – TMSOH] + at m/z 237 (14%), [M + – C10/C18] at m/z 185 (22%), [M + – C1/C12] at m/z 173 (10%), m/z 125 (12%), m/z 97 (16%), m/z 75 (39%), [SiMe 3 ] + at m/z 73 (100%). The spectrum was similar to that of compound 11 and indicated the structure of the oxiranyl vinyl carbinol 9,10-epoxy-13-hydroxy-11-octadecenoic acid (Me/ TMS) – EAS product – for compound 12 . The mass spectrum of additional 9( S )-HPOD conversion product 4 ( Fig. 5B ), 9 and 10-epoxy-11- hydroxy-12-octadecenoic acid (Me/TMS) – also EAS product, is described above. Thus, the main activity of the PpAOS2 F93 L mutant form towards 9-hydroperoxides was EAS activity. Besides, little amounts of compound 13 were also detected after the PpAOS2 F93 L mutant form incubations with 9( S )-HPOT ( Fig. 4B ) and 9( S )-HPOD ( Fig. 5B ). The mass spectrum of product 13 (not presented) matched that for 9-hydroxynonanoic acid (Me/TMS) ( Mukhtarova et al., 2011 ), thus demonstrating the formation of 9-oxononanoic acid via the 9-HPL route. The 9-oxononanoic acid (its mass spectrum matched that described by Mukhtarova et al., 2011 ) was also detected when the non-reduced products (Me/TMS) were subjected to the GC-MS analyses.

The results of incubations of the PpAOS2 F93 L mutant form with 13- hydroperoxides are discussed in the Supplementary Results. Briefly, while the mutant form mainly exhibited the EAS activity towards 9- hydroperoxides, 13-hydroperoxides conversion by this mutant form was less specific. The 13( S )-HPOD was converted mainly to the HPL products, less to the AOS products and least of all to the EAS products ( Table 2 ). The 13( S )-HPOT conversion went mainly to the AOS products, less to the HPL products, while the EAS products were only minorities ( Table 2 ).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 5. GC-MS analyses of products (Me/TMS) of 9( S )-HPOD conversions by recombinant WT ZmAOS1 ( А ), PpAOS2 F93L ( B ), and ZmAOS1 F95L ( C ). 1a and 1b , threo and erythro isomers of 9,10-dihydroxy-12-octadecenoic acid; 4 , 9,10-epoxy-11-hydroxy-12-octadecenoic acid; 12 , 9,10-epoxy-13-hydroxy-11- octadecenoic acid; 13 , 9-hydroxynonanoic acid. The structural formulae of products are presented in Fig. 2. 9-HOD, (9 S ,10 E ,12 Z )-9-hydroxy-10,12-octadecadienoic acid.

heading.emphasis: 2.5. Product specificities of the ZmAOS1 F95L mutant form

document.paragraph: The WT ZmAOS1 behaved as the specific AOS and produced the corresponding α− ketols ( Figs. 4A and 5A , Supplementary Fig. S1 , Supplementary Fig. S2 ). These α− ketols turned into the pairs of corresponding diastereomeric vic -diols upon their NaBH 4 reduction. The F95L mutation of ZmAOS1 did not completely impair the AOS activity. The mutant form still produced significant amount of α− ketols (detected as their NaBH 4 reduction products, vic -diols) upon its incubations with 9( S )-HPOT ( Fig. 4C ) and 9( S )-HPOD ( Fig. 5C ). At the same time, the ZmAOS1 F95 L mutant form also produced the oxiranyl carbinols 4 ( Fig. 5C ) and ( Fig. 4C ) – EAS product, as well as compound 13 – 9-hydroxynonanoic acid, HPL product.

The specificity exhibited by the ZmAOS1 F95 L mutant form towards the 13-hydroperoxides is discussed in the Supplementary Results. Briefly, while the mutant form mainly exhibited the AOS activity towards 9-hydroperoxides, 13-hydroperoxides were converted mainly to the HPL products, accompanied by minor AOS and EAS products ( Table 2 ).

heading.emphasis: 2.6. Product specificities of the LuAOS F155L mutant form

document.paragraph: In contrast to the above described mutant forms, the LuAOS F155 L mutant form did not show any qualitative alterations of catalytic activity compared to the wild type protein (data not presented). Conversion of 9( S )-HPOD, 9( S )-HPOT, 13( S )-HPOD, and 13( S )-HPOT by the LuAOS F155 L mutant form specifically afforded the corresponding α- ketol. The 13( S )-HPOT conversion besides with the α- ketol led to the cyclopentenone 12-oxo-10,15-phytodienoic acid, which is also the AOS product. Neither the HPL, DES nor EAS products were detected (results not presented).

subSection.paragraph:
Some primary determinants of catalysis by CYP74 enzymes have been revealed previously ( Lee et al., 2008 ; Toporkova et al., 2008 , 2013 , 2018a ). Substitution of the conserved amino acids at these sites might change the type of catalysis. One of these catalytic determinants, the “ F / L toggle” (SRS-1), was uncovered thanks to the X-ray 3D-structural analysis of
A. thaliana AOS
(AtAOS, CYP74A1) ( Lee et al., 2008 ). Importance of this site was confirmed by the conversion of the AOS to HPL activity upon Phe to Leu substitution by site-directed mutagenesis ( Lee et al., 2008 ). Nonetheless, the attempts of the Authors of work ( Lee et al., 2008 ) to make a reverse conversion by the Leu to Phe mutation at this site of HPL have failed (personal communication). The results of the present work provide new evidence for the catalytic significance of the “ F / L toggle” (SRS-1) for the catalysis of CYP74 enzymes.

To reveal the significance of the F / L toggle for allene oxide synthase catalysis, the mutant forms LeAOS3 F 108 L , ZmAOS1 F 95 L , LuAOS F 155 L , and PpAOS2 F 93 L were obtained and their catalytic specificities were examined. In contrast to the WT enzymes, which behaved as the specific AOSs, most of these mutant forms exhibited altered catalysis.

The results of the present work confirmed the importance of the “ F / L toggle” as the determinant of CYP74 catalysis. At the same time, the above-described data showed that the Phe to Leu replacement at this site of different AOSs does not necessarily lead to a creation of HPL activity. One of the studied enzymes, the LuAOS (CYP74A1) retained the AOS activity upon the F 155 L mutation. In contrast, the Phe/Leu mutant forms of three other AOSs, ZmAOS1, LeAOS3 and PpAOS2, possessed the significant changes of catalysis. The LeAOS3 F 108 L mutation resulted in partial AOS to EAS conversion. In turn, the ZmAOS1 F 95 L mutant form acquired the partial HPL activity. Finally, the PpAOS2 F 93 L mutant form possessed the altered catalysis and behaved largely as the EAS toward the 9-hydroperoxides and HPL toward the 13- HPOD . Moreover, 9- HPOD and 9- HPOT conversions by the EAS activity of the PpAOS2 F 93 L mutant form resulted in formation of oxiranyl vinyl carbinols as main products, whereas normally EASs produce mainly oxiranyl carbinols ( Lee et al., 2008 ; Toporkova et al., 2017a , b, 2018a, b, 2019).

Conversions of AOSs to HPLs by site-directed mutagenesis at several sites (including the SRS-1 ( Lee et al., 2008 ), the I-helix groove ( Toporkova et al., 2008 ), and the ERR triad ( Toporkova et al., 2008 )) have been described earlier. The results of the present work show that the same mutation causing the nearly complete AOS to HPL conversion with some enzymes does not necessarily lead to identical conversions in case of different proteins. Moreover, the same mutation may exceptionally have no consequences in the case of some proteins.

The present report described partial AOS into EAS conversion upon the site-directed mutagenesis. Some conversions of CYP74 enzymes catalysis caused by the site-directed mutagenesis, namely the AOS to HPL conversions ( Lee et al., 2008 ; Toporkova et al., 2008 , 2013 ), DES to AOS ( Toporkova et al., 2013 ) and double function HPL / EAS (CYP74 C ) to AOS ( Toporkova et al., 2018a ), have been described before. It is noteworthy in this connection that some plant AOSs produce the epoxyalcohols as the minor side products ( Song et al., 1993a ,b). All these data demonstrate the versatility of CYP74 catalysis, capability of CYP74 enzymes to undergo interconversions. The 18 O 2 labelling experiments with AOS ( Gerritsen et al., 1976 ), DES ( Crombie et al., 1991 ), HPL ( Grechkin and Hamberg, 2004 ; Grechkin et al., 2006 ) and EAS ( Toporkova et al., 2017a , b) showed the rearrangement mechanism proceeding via the epoxyallylic radical, which is a general intermediate of all CYP74 enzymes ( Fig. 6 ). Final transformations of the epoxyallylic radical occur either via a loss of a proton ( AOS , DES ), or the recombination of the epoxyallylic radical ( EAS ), or the vinyloxycarbinyl radical ( HPL ) with hydroxyl radical ( Fig. 6 ). Thus, four distinct types of catalytic activity are controlled by CYP74 enzymes, which are structurally and phylogenetically related. Their kinship creates the prerequisites for the conversion of the type of catalysis by the site-directed mutagenesis.

Flax plants (
L. usitatissimum
L ., cv. Novotorzhski) were grown in the fields near Kazan in summer 2017. The protonema of
P. patens
was grown on Knop medium ( Hershey, 1994 ) in 1 L pots in a growth chamber with a 16 h/8 h light/dark cycle at 22 ̊ C .

The pET-23a vector containing the open reading frame (ORF) of LeAOS3 gene was kindly provided to us by G. Howe. The ORF of ZmAOS1 gene was cloned by us in the рЕТ-32 Ek/LIC vector (Novagen, USA ) ( Grechkin et al., 2011 ).

Linoleic and α- linolenic acids, as well as the soybean lipoxygenase type V, were purchased from Sigma. NaBH 4 and silylating reagents were purchased from Fluka (Buchs, Switzerland ). (9
S
,10 E ,12 Z )-9- Hydroperoxy-10,12-octadecadienoic acid (9(
S
)- HPOD ) and (9
S
,10 E ,12 Z ,15 Z )-9-hydroperoxy-10,12,15-octadecatrienoic acid (9(
S
)- HPOT ) were prepared by incubation of linoleic and α- linolenic acids, respectively, with the recombinant maize 9-lipoxygenase (GeneBank:AAG61118.1) ( Wilson et al., 2001 ) in Na-phosphate buffer (100 mM, pH 6.0) at 0 ̊ C , under continuous oxygen bubbling. (9 Z ,11 E ,13
S
)-13-Hydroperoxy-9,11-octadecadienoic acid (13(
S
)- HPOD ) and (9 Z ,11 E ,13
S
,15 Z )-13-hydroperoxy-9,11,15-octadecatrienoic acid (13(
S
)- HPOT ) were obtained by incubation of linoleic and α- linolenic acids, respectively, with the soybean lipoxygenase type V in Tris-HCl buffer (50 mM, pH 9.0) at 23 ̊ C , under continuous oxygen bubbling. The extracted hydroperoxides (as free carboxylic acids) were purified by normal phase HPLC on Macherey-Nagel Nucleodur 100-3 silica column (250 × 4.6 mm , 3 μm) under the isocratic elution with the solvent mixture hexane/isopropanol/acetic acid (98.1:1.8:0.1, v/v) at a flow rate of 0.4 ml/min. Hydroperoxides were chromatographically pure and at least 98% optically pure, as judged by chiral phase HPLC ( Chechetkin et al., 2009 ).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 6. The mechanism of fatty acid hydroperoxide conversion by CYP74 proteins showing the role of the epoxyallylic radical as the general intermediate and its secondary conversions by separate enzymes. R = HOOC(CH 2 ) 7 –, R' = n -butyl.

subSection.paragraph:
Cloning of LuAOS (CYP74A1; GenBank P48417.1) and PpAOS2 (CYP74A8; GenBank XP_024372097.1) genes were performed using primers listed in Table 1 and pET-23a vector (Novagen, USA ). The total RNA was isolated from photosynthesising organs (stems and leaves) of 21 days old flax plants, as well as from 14 days old protonema of
P. patens
. The resulting constructions, as well as plasmids containing ORFs of LeAOS3 and ZmAOS1 genes were transferred into
Escherichia coli BL
21 (DE3)pLysS strain cells (Novagen, USA ). The recombinant wildtype enzymes and their mutant forms were obtained as follows. An overnight culture (10 mL) of bacteria was inoculated into 1 L of Luria-Bertani medium supplemented with one volume of mineral medium M 9. Bacteria were grown at 37 ̊ C , 250 rpm to an OD 600 of 0.6. Expression of the target genes was induced by addition of 0.5 mM isopropyl-β- D-1-thiogalactopyranoside to the medium. Simultaneously, the medium was supplied with 5-aminolevulinic acid to facilitate the haem formation. Inductions were controlled by the 12% SDS-PAGE analysis of crude cellular extracts. Bacteria were harvested by centrifugation for 15 min at 4500 rpm at 4 ̊ C and lysed with BugBuster Protein Extraction Reagent (Novagen, USA ). Purification of His-tagged recombinant proteins was performed using Bio-Scale Mini Profinity IMAC cartridge in BioLogic LP chromatographic system (Bio-Rad, USA ). The recombinant enzymes were eluted from the cartridge using 50 mM histidine. The recombinant protein concentrations were determined using the Quant-iT™ Protein HS Assay Kit (Invitrogen, USA ). The haemoprotein concentrations were estimated using the pyridine haemochromogen assay ( Schenkman and Jansson, 2006 ). The relative purity of recombinant proteins was estimated by SDS-PAGE and staining of the gel with Coomassie brilliant blue R-250. Enzymatic activities of the purified recombinant enzymes were determined by monitoring the decrease of the signal at 234 nm in a РВ 2201 В spectrophotometer (Solar, Belarus ) with 40 μM substrate concentration. The analyses were performed in 0.6 ml of Na-phosphate buffer (100 mM, pH 7.0) at 25 ̊ C .

The positioning of “ F / L toggle” in spatial structures of target CYP74s was performed using 3D models obtaining by ESyPred3D program ( Lambert et al., 2002 ) and the available X-ray models for allene oxide synthases (CYP74A) of
A. thaliana ( Lee et al., 2008 )
and
Parthenium argentatum ( Li et al., 2008 )
as the reference 3D structures.

The mutant forms of LeAOS3 , ZmAOS1 , LuAOS , and PpAOS2 genes were constructed by PCR using the primers listed in Table 1 and Pfu DNA polymerase (Promega, USA ). The mutations were confirmed by DNA sequencing using the 3130 Genetic Analyzer (Applied Biosystems, USA ).

heading.emphasis: 4.4. Incubations of recombinant enzymes with fatty acid hydroperoxides

subSection.paragraph: Products were analysed by GC-MS as described before ( Grechkin et al., 2006 ). The GC-MS analyses were performed using a Shimadzu QP5050A mass spectrometer connected to Shimadzu GC-17A gas chromatograph equipped with a Supelco MDN-5 S (5% phenyl 95% methylpolysiloxane) fused capillary column (length, 30 m ; ID 0.25 mm ; film thickness, 0.25 μm). Helium at a flow rate of 30 cm /s was used as the carrier gas. Injections were made in the split mode using an initial column temperature of 120 ̊ C , injector temperature 230 ̊ C . The column temperature was raised at 10 ̊ C /min until 240 ̊ C . The electron impact ionisation (70 eV) has been used.

Studies of ZmAOS1 F 95 L were carried out under financing from the Russian Science Foundation (Project No.16-14-10286). Studies of PpAOS2 F 93 L and LeAOS3 F 108 L were carried out with the financial support from the Russian Foundation for Basic Research (projects 16- 34-60231 and 18-04-00508, respectively). Studies of LuAOS F 155 L were supported by grant MK-5989.2018.4. Bioinformatics studies were carried out with the financial support from the government assignment for FRC Kazan Scientific Center of RAS.
Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https:// doi.org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2019.112152.
